{{DISPLAYTITLE:''Equus'' (play)}}{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} {{infobox playwright | name = Equus | image = Equusplaybookcover2.JPG | image_size = 150px | caption = | writer = [[Peter Shaffer]] | characters = {{plainlist | * Martin Dysart * Alan Strang * Frank Strang * Jill Mason * Hesther Soloman * Dora Strang * Nurse * Harry Dalton * Horseman * Nugget }} | setting = The Present; Rokeby Psychiatric Hospital, Southern England | premiere = 1973 | place = [[Royal National Theatre]] | orig_lang = English | subject = 17-year-old boy blinds six horses with spike, case becomes a catalyst for his psychiatrist's own doubts | genre = Drama | web = }} '''''Equus''''' is a play by [[Peter Shaffer]] written in 1973, telling the story of a [[psychiatrist]] who attempts to treat a young man who has a pathological religious fascination with horses.<ref name="greatbooks" />
Shaffer was inspired to write ''Equus'' when he heard of a crime involving a 17-year-old who blinded six horses in a small town near [[Suffolk]].<ref name="Pearce" /> He set out to construct a fictional account of what might have caused the incident, without knowing any of the details of the crime. The play's action is something of a detective story, involving the attempts of the [[Child and adolescent psychiatry|child psychiatrist]] Dr. Martin Dysart to understand the cause of the boy's actions while wrestling with his own sense of purpose.<ref name="equustheplay" />
The original stage production ran at the [[Royal National Theatre|National Theatre]] in London between 1973 and 1975, directed by [[John Dexter]]. [[Alec McCowen]] played Dysart, and [[Peter Firth]] played Alan Strang. Later came the Broadway productions that starred [[Anthony Hopkins]] as Dysart (later played by [[Richard Burton]], [[Leonard Nimoy]], and [[Anthony Perkins]]) and from the London production, Peter Firth as Alan. When Firth left for Broadway, [[Dai Bradley]] took over the role of Alan in the London production, playing opposite [[Michael Jayston]] as Dr. Dysart.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.infotextmanuscripts.org/webb/webb_nt_equus.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-04-05 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160412181555/http://www.infotextmanuscripts.org/webb/webb_nt_equus.pdf |archivedate=12 April 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Tom Hulce]] replaced Firth during the Broadway run. The Broadway production ran for 1,209 performances. [[Marian Seldes]] appeared in every single performance of the Broadway run, first in the role of Hesther and then as Dora. Shaffer also adapted his play for a 1977 film of the [[Equus (film)|same name]].
Numerous other issues inform the narrative. Most important are religious and [[ritual sacrifice]] themes, and the manner in which character Alan Strang constructs a personal theology involving the horses and the supreme [[Deity|godhead]], "Equus". Alan sees the horses as representative of God and confuses his adoration of his "God" with [[sexual attraction]]. Also important is Shaffer's examination of the conflict between personal values and satisfaction and societal mores, expectations, and institutions. In reference to the play's classical structure, themes, and characterisation, Shaffer has discussed the conflict between [[Apollonian and Dionysian]] values and systems in human life.
== Plot summary ==
===Act 1=== [[File:Equus-Dysart02Online.jpg|left|thumb|[[Charles S. Dutton]] as Dysart in ''Equus'', as directed by [[Brad Mays]] in May 1979 in [[Baltimore]]]] Martin Dysart is a psychiatrist in a mental hospital. He begins with a monologue in which he outlines the case of 17-year-old Alan Strang, who blinded six horses. He also divulges his feeling that his occupation is not all that he wishes it to be and his feelings of dissatisfaction and disappointment about his barren life. Dysart finds that the supply of troubled young people for him to "adjust" back into "normal" living is never-ending, but he doubts the value of treating these youths, since they will simply return to a dull, normal life that lacks any commitment and "worship" (a recurring theme). He comments that Alan Strang's crime was extreme, but adds that just such extremity is needed to break free from the chains of existence.
A court magistrate, Hesther Saloman, visits Dysart, believing that he has the skills to help Alan come to terms with what he did. At the hospital, Dysart has a great deal of difficulty making any kind of headway with Alan, who at first responds to questioning by singing TV advertising jingles.
Dysart reveals a dream he has had, in a [[Ancient Greece|Grecian]]/[[Homer]]ic setting, in which he is a public official presiding over a mass ritual sacrifice. Dysart slices open the abdomens of hundreds of children, and pulls out their entrails. He becomes disgusted with what he is doing, but fears being murdered in the same manner as the children if he is discovered as a "non-believer" by the other priests, so he does not stop. Eventually the other priests, aware of his misgivings, grab the knife from his hand before he awakens from the dream.
Dysart interviews Alan's parents. He learns that, from an early age, Alan has been receiving conflicting viewpoints on religion from his parents. Alan's mother, Dora, is a devout Christian who has read to him daily from the Bible. This practice has antagonized Alan's father Frank, a nonbeliever.
Slowly, Dysart makes contact with Alan by playing a game where each of them asks a question, which must be answered honestly.
Dysart learns that Frank, concerned that Alan has taken far too much interest in the more violent aspects of the Bible, destroyed a violent picture of the [[Crucifixion]] that Alan had hung at the foot of his bed. Alan replaced the picture with one of a horse, with large, staring eyes.
Alan reveals to Dysart that during his youth, he had established his attraction to horses by way of his mother's biblical tales, a horse story that she had read to him, Western movies, and his grandfather's interest in horses and riding. Alan's sexual training began with his mother who told him he could find true love and contentment by way of religious devotion and marriage. During this time, Alan also begins to develop a sexual attraction to horses, desiring to pet their thick coats, feel their muscular bodies, and smell their sweat. Alan reveals to Dysart that he had first encountered a horse at age six, on the beach. A rider approached him, and took him up on the horse. Alan was visibly excited, but his parents found him and Frank pulled him violently off the horse. The horse rider scoffed at the father and rode off.
Dysart hypnotizes Alan, and during the hypnosis, Dysart reveals elements of his terrifying dream of the ritual murder of children. Dysart begins to jog Alan's memory by filling in blanks, and asking questions. Alan reveals that he wants to help the horses by removing the bit, which enslaves them.
After turning 17, Alan took a job working in a shop selling electrical goods, where he met Jill Mason, an outgoing and free-spirited young woman. She visits the shop wanting to purchase blades for horse-clippers. Alan was instantly interested when he discovered that Jill has such close contact with horses after she tells him that she works for a local stable owner. Jill suggested that Alan work for the owner of the stables, Harry Dalton, and Alan agrees.
Dysart meets with Dalton, who tells him that he first held Alan to be a model worker, since he kept the stables immaculately clean and grooms the horses, including one named Nugget. Through Dysart's questioning, it becomes clear that Alan is erotically fixated on Nugget (or 'Equus') and secretly takes him for midnight rides, bareback and naked. Alan also envisions himself as a king, on the godhead Equus, both destroying their enemies.
===Act 2=== [[File:Equus-Jill&Alanoline.jpg|thumb|Lauren Raher and [[Brad Mays]] as Jill and Alan in ''Equus'', as directed by Mays in May 1979 in Baltimore]] Dysart gives Alan a placebo "truth pill". Revealing a tryst with Jill, he begins to re-enact the event. Jill, who had taken an interest in Alan, had asked him to take her to a porno theater. While there, they both ran into Frank. Alan was traumatized, particularly when he realized that his father was lying when he tried to justify his presence in the theater. However, this occurrence allows Alan to realize that sex is a natural thing for all men... even his father. Alan walks Jill home after they leave. She convinces Alan to come to the stables with her.
Once there, Jill seduces Alan and the two undress and attempt to have sex. However, Alan breaks this off when he hears the horses making noises in the stables beneath, which he decides is the reason for his inability to get an erection. Jill tries to ask Alan what the problem is, but he shouts at her to leave. After Jill dresses and walks out of the stables, the still nude Alan begs the horses for forgiveness, as he sees the horses as God-like figures. "Mine!...You're mine!...I am yours and you are mine!" cries Equus through Dysart's voice, but then he becomes threatening: "The Lord thy God is a jealous God," Equus/Dysart seethes, "He sees you, he sees you forever and ever, Alan. He sees you!...He sees you!" Alan screams, "''God seest!''" and then he says "No more. No more, Equus!" Alan then uses a steel spike to blind the six horses in the stable, whose eyes have "seen" his very soul.
The final scene has another monologue by Dysart questioning the fundamentals of his practice and whether or not what he does will actually help Alan, as the effect of his treatment will make him "normal" at the cost of his humanity.
== Original Broadway production== The play opened on Broadway at the [[Plymouth Theatre]] on 24 October 1974, ending on 11 September 1976. It then opened at the [[Helen Hayes Theatre]] on 5 October 1976, ending on 2 October 1977, for a total of 1,209 performances.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ibdb.com/broadway-production/equus-3484|title=Equus – Broadway Play – Original - IBDB|first=The Broadway|last=League|date=|website=www.ibdb.com|accessdate=9 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171010075301/https://www.ibdb.com/broadway-production/equus-3484|archivedate=10 October 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
== Film adaptation ==
{{main article|Equus (film)}}
Shaffer adapted the play for a 1977 film starring [[Richard Burton]], [[Peter Firth]], [[Eileen Atkins]], [[Colin Blakely]], [[Joan Plowright]], and [[Jenny Agutter]], directed by [[Sidney Lumet]]. Unlike stage productions, where the horses are portrayed by human actors, often muscular men wearing tribal-style masks,<ref>Richard Harland Smith , "[http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/17106/Equus/articles.html Equus (1977)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161025114601/http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/17106/Equus/articles.html |date=25 October 2016 }}," ''[[Turner Classic Movies]]'', URL accessed 24 October 2016.</ref> Lumet did not believe this could adequately be done in a film version, concluding a degree of realism was required, "because the reality he [Alan] was being watched in was going to create the dilemma within him."<ref>Ralph Applebaum, "Colour and Concepts," ''Sidney Lumet: Interviews'', University Press of Mississippi, 2006, p. 75.</ref>
Comparing the film to the play, English Professor James M. Welsh felt using real horses in the film was understandable, but argued the outdoor scenes infringed on the "abstract theatrical design" that gave the play its creativity.<ref>James M. Welsh, ''Video Versions: Film Adaptations of Plays on Video'', Greenwood Press, 2000, p. 111.</ref> Welsh also felt the explicit blinding was "potentially repulsive," and "much of the spirit of the play is lost as a consequence."<ref>Welsh, p. 112.</ref>
== Revivals{{anchor|Radcliffe}} == <!-- Please DO NOT add your production to this list unless it meets http://enwp.org/WP:42 . This is not a brochure for productions. -->
The Midwest premiere of ''Equus'' opened March 1978 in Lansing, Michigan, at Boarshead Theatre. Directed by John Peakes, it featured Richard Thomsen as Dysart, David Kropp as Alan, Carmen Decker as Dora, and Lisa Hodge as Jill. Local controversy over the nude scene was largely mitigated by casting a married couple as Jill and Alan. This production went on to win Boarshead Theatre's annual awards for Best Production and Best Supporting Actor (Kropp).<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/210449495/|title=Lansing State Journal from Lansing, Michigan on May 12, 1984 · Page 24|newspaper=Newspapers.com|language=en|access-date=28 January 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202052933/https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/210449495/|archivedate=2 February 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
''Equus'' was also presented in [[Baltimore]] in 1979 by the Lovegrove Alley Theatre. The production starred a pre-Broadway [[Charles S. Dutton]] in the role of Dysart. Director [[Brad Mays]] did double duty in the role of Alan Strang. A young actress named Lauren Raher played Jill Mason, and her real-life mother Rhona Raher portrayed Dora, Alan's mother.<ref name="Lord 1979" /><ref name="Strausbaugh 1979" /><ref name="Giuliano 1979" />
[[File:Daniel Radcliffe NY9.jpg|thumb|[[Daniel Radcliffe]] arrives for a performance of ''Equus'' in 2008]] ''Equus'' was revived in 2007 in the West End by producers [[David Pugh and Dafydd Rogers]], starring [[Richard Griffiths]], [[Daniel Radcliffe]], and [[Joanna Christie]] in the leading roles. The production was directed by [[Thea Sharrock]], and opened in February 2007 at the [[Gielgud Theatre]]. The production attracted press attention, as both Radcliffe and Griffiths appeared in the ''[[Harry Potter (film series)|Harry Potter]]'' film series (as [[Harry Potter (character)|Harry Potter]] and [[List of supporting Harry Potter characters#Vernon Dursley|Vernon Dursley]], respectively). In particular, the casting of then 17-year-old Radcliffe caused some controversy since the role of Alan Strang required him to appear nude on stage.<ref name="BBC 28 July 2006" /> Radcliffe insisted that the nude scene was not "gratuitous" and that he should portray the character and the scene as called for by the script.{{citation needed|date=June 2016}} The 2007 London revival was then transferred to Broadway, at the [[Broadhurst Theatre]], running through 8 February 2009. Radcliffe and Griffiths reprised their roles, and Thea Sharrock returned as director. The cast also included [[Kate Mulgrew]], [[Anna Camp]], [[Carolyn McCormick]], Lorenzo Pisoni, [[T. Ryder Smith]], Graeme Malcolm, and Sandra Shipley, with Collin Baja, [[Tyrone Jackson]], Spencer Liff, [[Adesola Osakalumi]], and Marc Spaulding.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/121672-Horse-Power-Equus-Revival-Opens-on-Broadway-Sept-25 |title=Horse Power: Equus Revival Opens on Broadway Sept. 25 |work=Playbill |accessdate=20 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029193351/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/121672-Horse-Power-Equus-Revival-Opens-on-Broadway-Sept-25 |archivedate=29 October 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> Radcliffe eventually received a nomination for the [[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Actor in a Play]].
The first illustrated edition of the play text was produced as a large-format artist's book by the Old Stile Press, with images and an afterword by the British artist [[Clive Hicks-Jenkins]], in 2009.<ref>Campbell, Nancy, Frances McDowall, Nicolas McDowall, The Old Stile Press... the Next Ten Years: A Bibliography 2000–2010 (2010: Old Stile Press) {{ISBN|978-0-907664-85-7}}</ref>
''Equus'' was revived in San Jose, California, in March 2011 at City Lights Theater Company.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sanjose.com/2011/03/23/review_equus/|title=City Lights Theatre: ‘Equus’|website=SanJose.com|access-date=29 December 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161230090440/http://www.sanjose.com/2011/03/23/review_equus/|archivedate=30 December 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> This production, featuring actors Sean Gilvary as Alan Strang and Steve Lambert as Martin Dysart, received rave reviews. [http://www.mercurynews.com/2011/03/21/review-equus-at-san-joses-city-lights/ ''The Mercury News''] labeled Gilvary and Lambert as "haunting," stating Gilvary "...exposing emotions and epidermis, rides bareback in every sense. He gradually manages to make a rather unattractive young creature seem not only sympathetic but redeemable while retaining his hostility and humanity."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/2011/03/21/review-equus-at-san-joses-city-lights/|title=Review: ‘Equus’ at San Jose’s City Lights – The Mercury News|access-date=29 December 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161230090705/http://www.mercurynews.com/2011/03/21/review-equus-at-san-joses-city-lights/|archivedate=30 December 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> [http://www.starkinsider.com/2011/03/theater-review-equus-at-city-lights-san-jose.html Starkinsider] rated the production 4.5 out of 5 stars, calling Lambert "superb" and having a "pitch-perfect performance," while calling Gilvary "dazzling" and having "a preternatural ability to inhabit the very soul of his character. Like the troubled teen that he portrays, both he and Strang possess a passion for something that is an inseparable part of their personality."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.starkinsider.com/2011/03/theater-review-equus-at-city-lights-san-jose.html|title=Theater Review: 'Equus' at City Lights, San Jose {{!}} Stark Insider|last=Writer|first=Guest|date=22 March 2011|newspaper=Stark Insider|language=en-US|access-date=29 December 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161230160603/http://www.starkinsider.com/2011/03/theater-review-equus-at-city-lights-san-jose.html|archivedate=30 December 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> This production received a Standout Classic Production Award by Silicon Valley Small Theatre Awards.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://artsalot.wordpress.com/2011/08/02/6th-annual-silicon-valley-small-venue-theatre-awards-the-2011-honorees/|title=6th Annual Silicon Valley Small Venue Theatre Awards – The 2011 Honorees!|last=Artsalot|date=2 August 2011|website=Artsalot|access-date=29 December 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161230090644/https://artsalot.wordpress.com/2011/08/02/6th-annual-silicon-valley-small-venue-theatre-awards-the-2011-honorees/|archivedate=30 December 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2013}} [[Image:Mink farm 1908.jpg|thumb|[[Mink]] farm (after 1900)]] [[Image:MinkFarmWisconsin2007.jpg|thumb|A [[mink]] farm in the United States]] [[File:Ferma norek w Polsce.jpg|thumb|A [[mink]] farm in [[Poland]]]] '''Fur farming''' is the practice of breeding or raising certain types of [[animal]]s for their [[fur]].
Fur used from animals caught in the wild is not considered farmed fur, and is instead known as "wild fur". Most of the world’s farmed fur is produced by European farmers. There are 5,000 fur farms in the [[European Union|EU]], all located across 22 countries; these areas of production collectively account for 50% of the global production of farmed fur.<ref>Sustainable Fur. (2017). Europe: Regulations. Retrieved from https://www.wearefur.com/responsible-fur/farming/fur-farming-europe/. Accessed on November 24th, 2018.</ref><ref name="International Fur Trade Federation">{{cite web | url = http://www.iftf.com/publctns/4849Intls_eEng.pdf| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110713004402/http://www.iftf.com/publctns/4849Intls_eEng.pdf| archivedate = 13 July 2011| title=The Socio-Economic Impact of International Fur Farming| author = International Fur Trade Federation| accessdate = 7 May 2009}}</ref> The EU accounts for 63% of global mink production and 70% of fox production. Denmark is the leading mink-producing country, accounting for approximately 28% of world production. Other major producers include China, the [[Netherlands]], [[Russia]], and the U.S.<ref>[http://www.furcommission.com/us-mink-state-of-the-industry-2011/ US Mink: State of the Industry – 2011]. Furcommission.com. Retrieved on 10 May 2012.</ref> [[Finland]] is the largest United States supplier of fox pelts. The United States is a major exporter of fur skins. Major export markets include China, Russia, Canada, and the EU. Exports to [[Asia]] as a share of total exports grew from 22% in 1998 to 47% in 2002.<ref>{{cite web | title=Industry & Trade Summary – Jan 2004 | url=http://www.usitc.gov/publications/332/pub3666.pdf}}</ref> China is the largest importer of fur pelts in the world and the largest exporter of finished fur products.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news|title= What are the rules on wearing fur? |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/magazine/4603032.stm|date=12 January 2006|accessdate=24 March 2008 | work=BBC News}}</ref>
Fur farming is banned in [[#Austria|Austria]],<ref>Charles Clover [https://web.archive.org/web/20040128175619/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/htmlContent.jhtml?html=%2Farchive%2F1999%2F05%2F13%2Fwmin13.html Europe kicks up a stink over British move to ban mink], [[Telegraph.co.uk]], 13 May 1999</ref><ref name="infurmation">[https://web.archive.org/web/20090116015047/http://www.infurmation.com/furfarmlegislation.php Fur Farming Legislation Around The World], Infurmation.com</ref> [[Croatia]],<ref name="infurmation" /><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090415190553/http://www.fashionfinland.com/en/news/article/fur_farmers_backed_into_a_corner/ Fur Farmers Backed into a Corner], fashionFINLAND.com, 2 January 2007</ref> the United Kingdom,<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/politics/1035944.stm MPs vote to ban fur farms]. BBC News, 22 November 2000. Retrieved on 10 May 2012.</ref><ref>[http://www.legislation.gov.uk/asp/2002/10/contents Fur Farming (Prohibition) (Scotland) Act 2002]. legislation.gov.uk. Retrieved on 28 May 2012.</ref>, the [[Czech Republic]] (effective in 2019)<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.furfreealliance.com/czech-fur-farming-ban-signed-president-zeman/ |title=Czech Fur Farming Ban Signed by President Zeman |date=5 August 2017 |website=Fur Free Alliance|publisher=Fur Free Alliance |access-date=10 August 2017 }}</ref> and [[Norway]] <ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.straitstimes.com/world/europe/norway-to-ban-fur-farms-as-fox-mink-go-out-of-fashion |title= Norway to ban fur farms as fox, mink go out of fashion |date=15 January 2018 |website=Straits Times|publisher=Straits Times |access-date=15 January 2018 }}</ref> In [[Germany]]<ref>http://www.peta.org/blog/germany-becomes-latest-country-ban-fur-farming/</ref> and Switzerland, the regulations for fur farming are very strict, with the result that there are no fur farms.<ref name=infurmation/> Some other countries have a ban on fur farming of certain types of animals.
Demand fell in the late 1980s and 1990s because of a number of factors, including the failure of designers to come up with exciting new lines, and the efforts of animal rights campaigners. Since the turn of the millennium, however, sales worldwide have soared to record highs, fueled by radically new techniques for working with fur, and a sharp rise in disposable income in China and Russia. This growing demand has led to the development of extensive fur farming operations in [[#China|China]] and [[Poland]].
==History== [[File:Felis catus (Domestic cat) fur skins.jpg|thumb|Cat skins]] While wearing fur clothing in cold weather as protection goes back to the Stone Age, the source for this material came from the wild. As human populations grew, furs, leathers, and hides for use in clothing came from farm stock, such as sheep (sheepskin), rabbits, cattle, pigs, and goats. The earliest records of breeding mink for fur in [[North America]] were in the 1860s. Foxes were first raised on farms for fur in [[Prince Edward Island]] in Canada in 1895.<ref name="International Fur Trade Federation"/>
Historically, the [[fur trade]] played an important economic role in the United States. Fur trappers explored and opened up large parts of North America, and the fashion for [[beaver hat]]s led to intense competition for the raw materials. Starting in the latter half of the 20th century, producers and wearers of fur have been criticized by animal rights activists because of the perceived [[cruelty to animals|cruelty]] they believe is involved in animal [[trapping (Animal)|trapping]] and because of the availability of substitutes such as synthetic fibers (made from petroleum oil).
Today, 80 percent of the fur clothing industry's pelts come from animals raised on farms. The rest is from animals caught in the wild. The most farmed fur-bearing animal is the mink (50 million annually), followed by the fox (about 4 million annually). Asiatic and Finnish raccoon and chinchilla are also farmed for their fur. 64 percent of fur farms are in Northern Europe, 11 percent are in North America, and the rest are dispersed throughout the world, in countries such as Argentina and Russia.<ref name="encarta">{{cite news |title=Fur Industry |url=http://encarta.msn.com/encyclopedia_761574462/fur_industry.html |publisher=[[MSN Encarta]] |accessdate=24 March 2008 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5kwpYHoMs?url=http://encarta.msn.com/encyclopedia_761574462/fur_industry.html |archivedate=1 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
==Species==
===Mink=== [[Image:Mink colours.jpg|thumb|Mink colours]] [[Mink]] have been farmed for fur in the United States for 130 years. In 2010, the U.S. ranked fifth in production behind [[mink industry in Denmark|Denmark]], China, the Netherlands, and Poland. Mink typically breed in March and give birth to their litters in May. Farmers vaccinate the young kits for botulism, distemper, enteritis, and, if needed, pneumonia. They are killed in November and December. Methods for [[animal euthanasia|euthanizing animals]] on fur farms, as on all farms, are detailed in the American Veterinary Medical Association's Report on Euthanasia which is used as a guideline for state departments of agriculture which have jurisdiction over all farms raising domesticated livestock, including mink.<ref>[https://www.avma.org/KB/Policies/Documents/euthanasia.pdf Guidelines on Euthanasia]. (PDF). avma.org. Retrieved on 4 December 2012.</ref>
The white [[mink]], a northern European breed, was introduced into Canada in 1968. Most mink production in Canada occurs in [[Nova Scotia]] which, with 116 licensed farms in 2016, generated revenues of nearly $54 million by contributing approximately 1.4 million pelts to global markets. That accounted for an average of half of all Canada's mink pelts .<ref> Nova Scotia Mink Breeders Association. (2016). "Mink Farming: Quick Facts". Retrieved from https://nsmink.ca/index.php/mink-farming</ref> Production of black mink in particular has grown significantly since 2000, with emerging markets in Russia, China, and [[South Korea]] accounting for most of the new demand. Black mink was first bred in Nova Scotia in the late 1950s and has proven popular as a versatile colour. Most Nova Scotia product is sold in China where it is manufactured into luxury garments.
===Chinchilla=== [[Image:Chinchilla-fur.JPG|thumb|Chinchilla]] [[File:Chinchilla148.jpg|thumb|A 2-year-old standard gray female chinchilla]] The international trade in [[chinchilla]] fur goes back to the 16th century and the animal (whose name literally means "Little Chincha") is named after the [[Chincha people]] of the [[Andes]], who wore its soft, dense fur. By the end of the 19th century, chinchillas had become quite rare. In 1923, Mathias F. Chapman brought the eleven wild chinchillas he had captured to the U.S. for breeding.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.edchinchillas.co.uk/The_Chin/chapman.html |title=Chapman Story |website=Edchinchillas.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2017-02-23}}</ref> Only three of these were female. Empress Chinchilla is the breeders association for the chinchilla farmers, many of whom are based in the United States, including California. Empress Chinchilla runs a certification program for farmers.[http://www.empresschinchilla.com/]
===Fox=== [[Image:Fur crossfox.jpg|thumb|"[[Cross fox (animal)|Cross fox]]" furs. The cross across the shoulders is a common [[Red fox]] marking.]] [[Image:Silver fox.jpg|thumb|Caged red fox [[Silver fox (animal)|(silver morph)]].]] [[Finland]] is the world's leading producer of [[fox]] pelts. In the United States, fox production is about 10,000 [[fur|pelts]], produced in about 10 states. [[Wisconsin]] and [[Utah]] have the most mink farms in the USA. Canada produces ten to fifteen times as many fox furs as the USA.<ref name="fur">{{cite news|author=Audrey Eggers|work=adapted from an article in the August/September 2002 issue of AgVentures|title= Farming For Fur |url=http://www.furcommission.com/farming/foxfarming.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721235245/http://www.furcommission.com/farming/foxfarming.htm|archivedate=21 July 2011|publisher=Fur Commission USA|accessdate=24 March 2008}}</ref>
===Dog and cat=== The United States banned the import, export, and sale of products made from dog and cat fur in 2000.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090530220220/http://www.happypaws.com.au/articles/the-trade-in-dog-and-cat-fur The trade in dog and cat fur], Happy Paws</ref> Italy, France, Denmark, [[Greece]], Belgium, and Australia ban the import of domestic cat and dog fur but the sale is still quasi-legal.<ref name="humane">{{cite news|title= Betrayal of Trust: the Global Trade in Cat and Dog Fur |url=http://www.hsicanada.ca/cat_dog_fur/|publisher=[[Humane society]]|accessdate=26 March 2008 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080321220309/http://www.hsicanada.ca/cat_dog_fur/ |archivedate = 21 March 2008}}</ref> In most countries, novelty items made from farmed cat and dog fur is available in the form of animal toys or as trim on garments like boots, jackets and handbags. The [[European Union]] banned imports in 2009.<ref name="salon">{{cite news|title= An Olympic disgrace |url=http://www.salon.com/opinion/feature/2008/03/24/animal_cruelty_china/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090201202844/http://www.salon.com/opinion/feature/2008/03/24/animal_cruelty_china/|archivedate=1 February 2009|author=Kerasote, Ted |date=24 March 2008|accessdate=26 March 2008}}</ref>
===Rabbit=== [[Image:Rabbit skins.jpg|thumb|A load of rabbit skins (c. 1905)]] The main breed in the [[rabbit]] fur farming industry is the [[list of rabbit breeds#Rex|Rex]] (Castor Rex and Chinchilla Rex). Breeding animals are kept for up to 3 years, and usually [[give birth]] twice a year. The [[rabbit|kits]] are taken from their mothers at 4 weeks old and put in a nursery with other kits. After this, the mothers are kept separated from their kits, and they get put together only for feeding. When the kits are 7 to 8 weeks old, they are put in solitary cages, where they are kept for about 6–7 months, and are harvested after they have [[moulting|shed]] their winter fur. The rabbits are kept in bare [[wire mesh]] [[cage (enclosure)|cage]]s. A cage for one rabbit has the floor space of about two shoe boxes. The [[mortality rate]] for caged Rex is 10 – 15%, mostly from [[respiratory disease]].<ref name="rabbitfur">{{cite news|title= Rabbit fur: face the facts |url=http://www.rabbitfur.org/factsheet.htm|publisher=[[The Coalition to Abolish the Fur Trade|The Coalition to Abolish the Fur Trade (CAFT)]]|accessdate=28 March 2008}}</ref>
==Farmed Mink Production Cycle== ===Conditioning and Breeding (December - March)=== During this time of year, ranchers are primarily focused on bringing their selected mink into a good condition that is suitable for breeding. Mink are a monoestrous species that undergo delayed implantation when bred successfully, this means that the breeding season can be the most strenuous time of year both in terms of animal nutrition and human labor.<ref>Felska-Blaszczyk, L., Lawrow, N., Lasota, B., Seremak, B., Pezinska-Kijak, K., Zuk, K., and Nowak, P. (2018). The Sex Ratio in Farmed American Mink (''Neovison vison''). ''Archives of Animal Breeding'', 61 (2018), 359 - 363. Retrieved from file:///C:/Users/User/Downloads/The_sex_ratio_in_farmed_Americ.pdf. Accessed on November 24th, 2018.</ref> It is essential that management practices employ a feeding program that maintains a nutritional diet that is adequate for both male and female mink. A feeding program that encourages the removal of excess weight and an environment that facilitates an increase in exercise is important for good production and a successful whelp.<ref name=CMBA> Canada Mink Breeders Association.(n.d.). "A Year on a Mink Farm". Retrieved from (http://canadamink.webtext.ca/cmbfarm.shtml Retrieved on November 22nd, 2018.</ref> Mink are usually fed once or twice a day during the growing season; on most farms they are fed the same quantity of food on all cages and close to an ''ad libitum'' amount so that 50% of all cages have feed left over the next day. <ref>Hansen, S. W. and Moller, S.H. (2007). Diurnal Activity Patterns of Farm Mink (Mustela vison) Subjected to Different Feeding Routines. ''Journal of Applied Animal Behaviour Science,''111 (2008), 146 - 157.</ref> Not only does the rancher select for fur quality and production traits, their major concentration is on the health and temperament of the animal; all of these traits will correlate with the overall [[animal welfare|welfare]] of the herd. <ref name=NFACC> National Farm Animal Care Council.(2013). "Code of Practice: For the Care and Handling of Farmed Mink". Retrieved from (http://canadamink.webtext.ca/2013-06_Mink_Code_of_Practice.pdf Retrieved on November 22nd, 2018.</ref>. Breeding records are kept for each individual mink, this includes information on the dates of mating, genetics involving family lineage, reproductive success, health status, and fur characteristics. <ref name=CMBA />.
===Whelping and Weaning (April - June)=== In preparation for [[whelping|whelping]], comfortable conditions are prepared for the female by providing ample aspen bedding in which she can create a nest. It is well-known that female mink are highly motivated to perform maternal-related nest building during the majority of their gestation period <ref>Schou, T.M., Palme, R., and Malmkvist, J. (2018). Prolonged Nest Building Increase the Reproductive Outcome in American Female Mink. ''Journal of Applied Animal Behaviour Science'', 207 (2018), 98 - 107. Retrieved from https://reader.elsevier.com/reader/sd/pii/S016815911830114X?token=06A5DE50F9FCF3A8D1E799844ABB066C7F56DF32DA75F853DD736EF7574522FB758BC4E1B5CCD0FEE75BE036E6480F1B. Accessed on November 24th, 2018.</ref>, this is why providing an abundance of substrate to prepare a nest is crucial to maintain the animals welfare. Unnecessary stress and noises are avoided so due to the sensitivity of female mink during late gestation. Gestation varies from 40-70 days, this time is often shortened by extending the daylight period by use of artificial lighting. <ref name=CMBA />. Females give birth to 5-6 kits on average. Since [[mink|kits]] are born [[altricial|altricial]], the female spends most of her time in the [[nest box|nest boxes]] caring for them. Mink kits are fully dependent on the dam's milk and will nurse for the first four weeks of their life. <ref>Brink, A.L., Jeppesen, L.L., and Heller, K.E. (2004). Behaviour in Suckling Mink Kits Under Farm Conditions: Effects of Accessibility of Drinking Water. ''Journal of Applied Animal Science'', 89 (2004), 131 - 137</ref> Maternal care is essential to promote offspring survival and growth, particularly in American mink who give birth to altricial young. <ref>Schou, T.M., and Malmkvist, J. (2017). Early Kit Mortality and Growth in Farmed Mink are Affected by Litter Size Rather than Nest Climate. ''The Animal Consortium'', 11 (9), 1581 - 1589. Retrieved from https://www.cambridge.org/core/services/aop-cambridge-core/content/view/BE1E6A1B57E8C2062E833333FC48331E/S1751731117000234a.pdf/early_kit_mortality_and_growth_in_farmed_mink_are_affected_by_litter_size_rather_than_nest_climate.pdf. Accessed on November 24th, 2018.</ref> Ranchers will check them regularly to ensure all the kits are warm, receiving enough milk, and are growing well. Females can loose significant body condition during [[lactation|lactation]] so their health is monitored by visual observations of behavior, appearance, and feed consumption.<ref name=CMBA />. [[Weaning|Weaning]] takes place when the kits reach approximately 6-8 weeks old. The changes that take place during weaning can be stressful for both [[dam|dam]] and kits therefore is done at a time that is most beneficial for the mother and litter. Ranchers will ensure the kits are able to consume solid [[animal feed|feed]] and drink water independently before they are ready for weaning. <ref name=NFACC />.
===Growth and Furring (July - October)=== Very rapid growth takes place during the growth phase of the production cycle. For about 10-11 weeks, it is critical that the juvenile kits have access to adequate amounts of feed that is formulated to meet their nutritional needs. Maintaining a feeding routine that allows for multiple distributions of feed a day will help keep feed fresh and encourage appetite. <ref name=NFACC />. In July, all mink (including kits and adult breeders) are vaccinated to prevent diseases and promote health and welfare of the herd. Once August arrives, the skeletal growth of kits is complete and the subsequent growth of primarily fat begins. The growth of fur predominantly takes place during the fall where it begins at the tail and continues up the back and to the head. Ranchers maintain a clean, healthy environment during this time by performing daily [[husbandry|husbandry]] practices, this includes; cleaning nest boxes, removal of surrounding debris and manure from the barn, bedding the cages, and up-keeping the cleanliness of the facility and farming equipment. Ranchers are diligent toward creating an environment that prioritizes the welfare of each animal and allows them to live and function comfortably within their environment.
===Grading and Harvesting (November - December)=== Mink are carefully evaluated in November or early December in order to physically assess their coat color, characteristics, and quality. Fur quality, along with skin size are two of the most important traits that are under intense selection in most mink breeding programs.<ref>Thirstrup, J.P., Jensen, J., and Lund, M.S. (2016). Genetic Parameters for Fur Quality Graded on Live Animals and Dried Pelts of American Mink (''Neovison vison''). ''Journal of Animal Breeding and Genetics'', 134 (2017), 322 - 331. Retrieved from https://onlinelibrary-wiley-com.ezproxy.library.dal.ca/doi/epdf/10.1111/jbg.12258. Accessed on November 24th, 2018</ref> Each mink will be given a grade dictated by the attributes of their coat; this is valuable in determining which mink will be kept as breeding stock for next season. Fur quality, color, and body size are judged by the farmer or a professional grader. <ref>Lagerkvist, G. (1997). Economic Profit from Increased Litter Size, Body Weight and Pelt Quality in Mink (''Mustela vison''). ''ACTA Agriculture Scandinavica'', 47 (1997), 57 0 63. Retrieved from https://www.tandfonline.com/action/journalInformation?journalCode=saga20. Accessed on November 28th, 2018.</ref> Fur grades are often used alongside size, weight, health history, parent reproductive success, litter size, and temperament to assess the quality and potential of each animal<ref name=CMBA />. Mink are harvested in December and methods are used to euthanize each animal so that their death is quick, humane, and as painless as possible. Several techniques have been considered proper to euthanize farmed mink, these include; neck breaking, electricity, carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, nitrogen, argon, and lethal injection. <ref>Korhonen, H.T., Cizinauskas, S., and Jesernics, J. (2012). Electrophysiological Study on CO and CO2 Euthanasia in Mink (''MUSTELA VISON''). ''Annals of Animal Science'', 12 (4), 597 - 608. Retrieved from file:///C:/Users/User/Downloads/Electrophysiological_study_on_.pdf. Accessed on November 24th, 2018.</ref> The most common method of harvesting is by subjecting the animal to a chamber that contains [[carbon monoxide|carbon monoxide]]. Pelting takes place either on site or upon shipping the mink to an offsite operation. <ref name=CMBA />.
==By-products== After pelting, fur farms dispose of their dead animals as economically as possible. The mink bodies are typically sent for either incineration or rendering where they can be converted into bone and meat meal. <ref> Zarkadas, I., Dontis, G., Pilidis, G., and Sarigiannis, D.A. (2016). Exploring the Potential of Fur Farming Wastes and Byproducts as Substrates to Anaerobic Digestion Process. ''Journal of Renewable Energy'', 96 (2016), 1063 - 1070. Retrieved from https://ac-els-cdn-com.ezproxy.library.dal.ca/S0960148116302403/1-s2.0-S0960148116302403-main.pdf?_tid=e1c03182-bb33-4fa0-af5b-43ea702b1dd7&acdnat=1542852861_119fc1d0ffb3fc1d725886952e28b5f8 Retrieved on November 22nd, 2018.</ref> The meat from most fur-bearers is not usually eaten by humans, therefore the carcasses will go on to become various products such as [[pet food]], animal feed, organic compost, fertilizer, paint, and even tires. Carcasses sometimes go to animal sanctuaries, zoos, and aquariums to feed animals, and some end up as crab bait. Some biological supply companies offer preserved skinned carcasses of ranched mink for classroom [[dissection]] specimens as an alternative to cats or other domesticated mammals. Mink feces are used as organic crop fertiliser, and mink fat is turned into oil to manufacture soap, face oils, cosmetics, and leather treatments.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.montanatrappers.org/management/fur-farming.htm#.VIDGfYs8-LM |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20040402073526/http://montanatrappers.org/management/fur-farming.htm#.VIDGfYs8-LM |dead-url= yes |archive-date= 2 April 2004 |title=Fur Farming |first= |last=|work=montanatrappers.org |year=2014 |accessdate=4 December 2014}} </ref>
==The Environmental Sustainability of Fur== Once acting as a way to symbolize ones social status, fur garments are now recognized as a unique fashion item that is desired by consumers all around the world<ref>Lee, N., Kim, N., Kim, G., and Ha, J. (2017). Industrial - Education Collaboration Case Study for Fur Design Education. ''International Journal of Interdisciplinary Research'', 4 (11), 1 - 12. Retrieved from https://link.springer.com/content/pdf/10.1186%2Fs40691-017-0096-y.pdf Retrieved on November 23rd, 2018</ref>. Using products that are sustainable and environmentally friendly has become a top priority to many global citizens and real fur products offer a way in which to support these initiatives. Real fur is an organic material that remains as one of the most eco-friendly fabrics in the fashion industry <ref name=NAFA>North American Fur Auctions. (2018). Fur: Eco-Friendly. Retrieved from http://www.nafa.ca/resources/ Retrieved on November 23rd, 2018.</ref>. Many synthetic materials such as fake fur are made using [[petrochemicals|petrochemicals]]; these materials do not easily break down and will remain in landfills for centuries. By wearing real fur instead of fake, consumers can decrease the lasting environmental impacts of [[fast fashion|fast fashion]]<ref>Claudio, L. (2007). Waste Couture: Environmental Impact of the Clothing Industry.''Environmental Health Perspectives'', 115 (9), 449 - 454. Retrieved from file:///C:/Users/User/Downloads/Waste_Couture_Environmental_I.pdf. Accessed on November 24th, 2018 </ref>. When maintained and treated with care, fur can withhold a resilient and long lasting nature and even be passed done for many generations. While they are designed to be durable and functional for decades of use, fur garments will eventually deteriorate and return to nature; since it is an animal product and [[biodegradable|biodegradable]], it can be easily composted and reused<ref>Fur Council of Canada. (n.d.) Fur is Green. Retrieved from http://www.furisgreen.com/furisgreen.aspx. Retrieved on November 23rd, 2018.</ref>. Not only is authentic fur recyclable, but its production is a renewable resource. Pelts that are produced commercially come from domestic mink that are selectively bred and harvested each year; no interference with wild or endangered species takes places to produce a farmed mink pelt. With the proper care and and eye for fashion, a fur garment can even be reinvented from a coat to jacket to vest to liner, to home accessory. <ref name=NAFA />
==Controversy== {{commons category|Animal abuse in fur farming}} Anti-fur activists have claimed that methods used on fur farms are focused on maximizing profits at the expense of the welfare of fur producing [[livestock|animals]].<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://www.peta.org/issues/animals-used-for-clothing/animals-used-clothing-factsheets/inside-fur-industry-factory-farms/|title=Inside the Fur Industry: Factory Farms|work=PETA|access-date=2017-07-11|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name="Frequent">{{cite news|title=Frequent Reasons for buying Fur|url=http://fur.elehost.com/frequent_reasons.html|publisher=fur.elehost.com|accessdate=24 March 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080312054532/http://fur.elehost.com/frequent_reasons.html|archivedate=12 March 2008|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="house">{{cite news|title= House of Commons Hansard Debates for 5 Mar 1999 (pt 6)|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm199899/cmhansrd/vo990305/debtext/90305-06.htm| date=5 March 1999| accessdate=24 March 2008}}</ref>
As with other types of [[animal farming]], living conditions of animals vary, and extreme cases are of much contention. According to PETA, the majority of fur farmers pack animals into small cages, preventing them from taking more than a few steps back and forth. PETA claims [[fox]]es and other animals suffer as a result of the confined environment, and may even cannibalize each other as a reaction to their confinement.<ref name=":3" /> In other cases, as with passing of animal welfare legislation in Italy, animals are required to be given enriched living environments in which they can climb on branches, dig holes, use a nest of 50 × 50 cm and also have a water basin of at least 2 × 2 metres and 50 cm deep in which to swim.<ref name = "Dieren">{{cite web | title= Support Our Efforts for Animal Rights | work= Bont voor Dieren | url =http://www.bontvoordieren.nl/english/index.php?action=farming | accessdate= 29 December 2005 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20051215121641/http://www.bontvoordieren.nl/english/index.php?action=farming |archivedate = 15 December 2005}}</ref> Farmers argue that 50 years ago, the animals were kept in large outdoor holding areas, with pools of water. However, such farms resulted in high disease rates for the animals and were not practical. Farmers claim that today's farmed animals only know farm life as they have been domesticated through over hundreds of years of selective breeding.{{citation needed| date = April 2012}} The methods used for slaughtering the animals on farms and in the wild vary depending on the animal. For farmed mink, the [[American Veterinary Medical Association]] researches the best methods and publishes a report on the subject every 7 to 10 years. This report is used to guide state departments of agriculture which have jurisdiction over farm animals, including farm-raised mink. For those harvesting wild furs, biologists and wildlife managers dictate seasons, method of slaughter, and numbers of animals to be harvested.
===United Kingdom=== {{main article|Fur Farming (Prohibition) Act 2000|Fur Farming (Prohibition) (Scotland) Act 2002}}
After UK mink farmers were subjected to almost daily protests, they agreed to shut down their farming in exchange for compensation in [[England and Wales]] in 2000. At [[second reading]], the ban in England and Wales was justified principally on grounds of public morality.<ref name="Dieren" /> Prior to the ban, there had been 11 fur farms in the UK producing about 100,000 pelts annually.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/politics/1034562.stm |title=Campaigners hail fur ban bill |date=22 November 2000 |newspaper=[[BBC News Online]]}}</ref> Although the last fur farm in Scotland had closed in 1993, the [[Scottish Parliament]] nevertheless banned fur farming in 2002. Fur farming was also banned in [[Northern Ireland]] in 2002 under the Fur Farming (Prohibition) (Northern Ireland) Order 2002.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Fur Farming (Prohibition) (Northern Ireland) Order 2002|url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/nisi/2002/3151/contents|website=Legislation.gov.uk|publisher=HM Government|accessdate=12 March 2017}}</ref>
===Austria=== In Austria, six of the nine federal states have banned fur farming, and the remaining three enforce such strict welfare regulations, in relation to the availability of swimming water, that fur farming is no longer economically viable.<ref name = "Dieren" />
===Republic of Ireland===
In the [[Republic of Ireland]] there are currently three<ref name="independent.ie">http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/news/the-mink-behind-the-wire-inside-irelands-fur-farms-30495738.html</ref> fur farms in operation. These farms focus mainly on the trade of mink fur (some farms which have used fox fur are currently winding down operation as such trade is no longer economically viable). In 2006, approximately 170,000 mink and 300 foxes were harvested in the Republic of Ireland.<ref>[http://www.ciwf.ie/farminfo/farmfacts_fur.html Compassion In World Farming Ireland – Irish Farming Facts]. Ciwf.ie. Retrieved on 10 May 2012.</ref> Furs are exported from the Republic of Ireland to other EU member states or to countries in Asia and North America. In the Republic of Ireland, fur farms are monitored by the [[Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine|Department of Agriculture]], and welfare standards of Ireland and the European Union must be adhered to at all times. In October 2009, there were discussions within the political sphere on the banning of fur farms in the Republic of Ireland.<ref name="irishtimes.com">{{cite news| url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2009/1012/1224256435727.html | work=The Irish Times | title=Plan focuses on electoral reform, education spend | date=10 October 2009}}</ref> Animal welfare groups have welcomed such proposals,<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2009/1012/1224256435882.html | work=The Irish Times | title=Animal welfare groups welcome ban on fur farming | date=10 October 2009}}</ref> though concern has been highlighted, in terms of its impact on rural communities where alternative industries are scarce. Fur farming in the Republic of Ireland contributes about €15 million per year to the economy.<ref name="independent.ie"/> A ban was subsequently passed before being overturned by Minister for Agriculture at the time [[Simon Coveney]] of Fine Gael after the party formed a new government following the 2011 election. There is a renewed campaign and ongoing efforts to push the Irish government or current Minister for Agriculture [[Michael Creed]] to re-implement a phase-out ban. <ref>[https://www.rte.ie/entertainment/2018/0219/941728-morrissey-urges-irish-ban-on-fur-farming/]. rte.ie. Retrieve on 14 March 2018</ref>
===Netherlands=== Fur farming of chinchillas and foxes is banned. Legislation to phase out mink fur farming (and thereby effectively all fur farming) by 2024 was approved by the end of 2012.<ref>{{cite news |title=Dutch law will ban mink farming by 2024 |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/lifestyle/report_dutch-law-will-ban-mink-farming-by-2024_1779060 |newspaper=[[Daily News and Analysis]] |date=18 December 2012 |accessdate=26 December 2012 |agency=Reuters}}</ref>
===China=== The State Forestry Administration (SFA) is set to offer training courses for fur farmers.<ref name="china.org.cn">{{cite web | title=Regulations to Improve Wildlife Welfare | url=http://www.china.org.cn/english/GS-e/159563.htm}}</ref> Legislation was drafted in September 2009 to address any cruelty to animals in China. If passed, the legislation would regulate how farm animals are raised, transported, and slaughtered.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.telegraph.co.uk/news/peterwedderburn/100010449/china-unveils-first-ever-animal-cruelty-legislation/|title=China unveils first ever animal cruelty legislation|date=18 September 2009|accessdate=18 September 2009 | work=The Daily Telegraph | location=London}}</ref> In 2005, animals right group The Swiss Animal Protection accused the Chinese of skinning fur-bearing animals including the "Asiatic raccoon" ([[raccoon dog]]) while still alive, and produced a controversial video on the subject.<ref>[http://www.theepochtimes.com/news/7-2-21/51905.html Dogs and Cats Skinned Alive for Their Fur in China]. The Epoch Times (21 February 2007). Retrieved on 23 December 2013.</ref><ref>[http://www.peta.org/feat/ChineseFurFarms/index.asp A Shocking Look Inside Chinese Fur Farms]. PETA.org. Retrieved on 23 December 2013.</ref> The China Fur Commission and China Leather Industry Association challenged the authenticity of the video, stating: "Pictures showing animals being skinned alive are obviously plotted. All those with common sense would not choose this slaughter method to attain fur."<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100214125453/http://www.china-embassy.ch/ger/4/t185836.htm Announcement by China Fur Commission, China Leather Industry Association]. china-embassy.ch (4 March 2005)</ref> The government of Suning County, Hebei Province also issued a statement, outlining welfare practices it claimed to practice on its fur farms and calling the alleged practice of skinning animals alive "unimaginable."<ref>[http://old.furcommission.com/news/newsC72.htm Statement from The People's Government of Suning County] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131224095553/http://old.furcommission.com/news/newsC72.htm |date=24 December 2013 }}. Old.furcommission.com (22 April 2005). Retrieved on 10 May 2012.</ref> Swiss Animal Protection later published a video showing the live skinning of raccoon dogs and other canines. The video shows raccoon dogs being beaten with sticks and thrown against the ground in an attempt to stun them before being hung from their rear legs and skinned alive. In another film a worker begins to cut the skin and fur from an animal's leg. The animal is still alive breathing and kicking. The free limbs kick and writhe making it difficult for the worker to cut the skin from the animal's body. The worker stamps on the animal's neck and head. One investigator filmed a raccoon dog being skinned alive before being thrown onto a heap of carcasses. After the skinning the animal still had enough strength to lift its bloodied head and stare into the camera.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/article/291483 |title=China accused of skinning live animals for fur [graphic video] (Includes interview) |website=Digitaljournal.com |date=2010-05-02 |accessdate=2017-02-22}}</ref> Several local Chinese animal welfare groups have reported these cruel practices as commonplace.<ref>{{Zh}} [http://www.vshine.org.cn/news_detail_project/newsId=571.html VShine Animal Protection Association: Fur Survey] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518102802/http://www.vshine.org.cn/news_detail_project/newsId%3D571.html |date=18 May 2015 }}</ref>
===Finland=== Finnish citizens have had a right to instigate parliamentarian law initiatives since 2012. The first citizens' initiative to gain enough signatures was that instituting a ban on fur farming. Some 70,000 citizens signed the initiative within the required time period in 2013.<ref>[http://yle.fi/uutiset/parliament_mulls_how_to_deal_with_citizens_initiatives/6534855 Parliament mulls how to deal with citizens’ initiatives] yle.fi. 13 March 2013</ref> In a march to [[Parliament House, Helsinki]] on 18 June.<ref>[http://yle.fi/uutiset/100s_march_against_fur_farming/6694982 100s march against fur farming]. yle.fi 18 June 2013</ref>, four to five hundred people appealed to members of parliament to approve the citizens' initiative to ban fur farming. According to animal expert MSc Sesse Koivisto (wife of Ilkka Koivisto ex-director of the zoo [[Korkeasaari]]) in Helsingin Sanomat in 2010, fur farming did not provide acceptable conditions for the animals. In order to stop the suffering of animals, she demanded a ban on fur farming in Helsingin Sanomat, as in some other countries.<ref>[http://luonnonvarassa.vuodatus.net/lue/2010/02/kurjuuden-ylistys Kurjuuden ylistys]. vuodatus.net. 27 February 2010</ref> On 19 June 2013, the [[Jyrki Katainen's cabinet|Finnish Parliament]] rejected the first citizens' initiative to ban fur farming. A positive development in the [[politics of Finland]] was that the initiative was taken in the Parliament for public voting.<ref>[http://yle.fi/uutiset/parliament_says_no_to_fur-farming_ban/6696170 Parliament says no to fur-farming ban Parliament says no to fur-farming ban]. yle.fi. 19 June 2012</ref><ref>[http://yle.fi/uutiset/turkistarhauksen_kielto_kaatui_aanin_146-36/6695753 Turkistarhauksen kielto kaatui äänin 146-36]. yle.fi 19 June 2012</ref>
In Finland in August 2016, there were about 950 active fur farms. The breeding of fur-animals has had a long tradition in Finland, having been professionally conducted since the 1920s. Up to 90% of the fur-farming community is situated in the rural areas of [[Ostrobothnia (region)|Ostrobothnia]] and employs four to six thousand people. Today, fur farming is strictly regulated by law. The Finnish Furbreeders Association has developed its own national program of certification and animal health welfare that is tied to the [http://www.iso.org/iso/home/standards/management-standards/iso_9000.htm ISO 9001 standard] and monitored by the [http://www.detnorskeveritas.com/about/purpose/ Norske Veritas.] The fur animals are housed in shelter buildings or halls, where each animal has a specific place marked with a kit card. Shelter buildings are suitable for all fur animals, but halls are only used in mink farming.
=== Estonia === Estonian citizens have a partial right to submit initiatives with at least 1000 signatures to the [[Riigikogu|parliament]] since 2014. web|url=http://news.err.ee/v/74cc9fd8-df66-4044-b60b-e5e1e527510d|title=Over 10,000 signatures given to ban fur farming|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Estonian Public Broadcasting|access-date=2016-08-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://petitsioon.ee/karusloomafarmid|title=Aita keelustada karusloomafarmid!|last=|first=|date=|website=petitsioon.ee|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-31}}</ref> This was preceded by secretly filmed anonymous documentary footage being aired both online via [[YouTube]] and on [[Eesti Televisioon|Estonian National Television]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uudised.err.ee/v/eesti/16901937-fd60-48b0-bc6c-b311ea401097|title=Eesti naaritsafarmid tegutsevad aastaid loata|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Pealtnägija, Estonian Public Broadcasting|access-date=2016-08-31}}</ref> depicting the conditions of the animals in 2012 (aired 2013) and 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uudised.err.ee/v/eesti/5190f943-9bb9-4c26-a0f0-8d180b1efb2b|title=Loomaõiguslaste salavideo näitas karusloomakasvatuse telgitaguseid|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Estonian Public Broadcasting|access-date=2016-08-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://loomadenimel.ee/karusnahalugu/kampaaniast/|title=Karusnaha lugu|last=|first=|date=2014-11-05|website=|publisher=Loomade Nimel/In the Name of Animals|access-date=2016-08-31}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{cite web|url=http://loomadenimel.ee/karusnahalugu/uncategorized/press-release-undercover-footage-exposes-the-estonian-fur-industry-once-again/|title=Press release: Undercover footage exposes the Estonian fur industry once again|last=|first=|date=2014-11-20|website=|publisher=Loomade Nimel/In the Name of Animals|access-date=2016-08-31}}</ref> The Estonian animal advocacy organization Loomus issued a comment after the airings of [[Estonian Public Broadcasting]] outlining the documented disregard animal welfare regulations and pointing out the numerous injuries of animals that were documented.<ref name=":1" /><ref name="Estonian Public Broadcasting">{{cite web|url=http://news.err.ee/v/ebbe322d-9fc2-4ea1-8a95-2f630f674c28|title=Video of Fur Farm Operating Without License Provokes Outrage|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Estonian Public Broadcasting|access-date=2016-08-31}}</ref>
The petition has since been under review in the commission of agricultural affairs.<ref name=":2">{{cite web|url=http://www.postimees.ee/v2/3776755/padar-maaelukomisjon-otsustab-karusloomakasvatuste-saatuse-kiiresti|title=Padar: maaelukomisjon otsustab karusloomakasvatuste saatuse kiiresti|website=Postimees|access-date=2016-08-31|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160911131732/http://www.postimees.ee/v2/3776755/padar-maaelukomisjon-otsustab-karusloomakasvatuste-saatuse-kiiresti|archivedate=11 September 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The commission procured a study on the economic significance of the industry from the [[Estonian University of Life Sciences]] published in 2016, which did not state the exact number of farms in existence but did outline that the mink and fox farms employed 74 full-time workers in 2014, with the majority concentrated in the largest factory in the [[Baltic states|Baltic States]], in [[Karjaküla]], near [[Tallinn]].<ref name="Estonian Public Broadcasting"/><ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=http://www.pikk.ee/upload/files/Karusloomakasvatuse_uuring_1.pdf|title=Final Report - A Study on Fur Farming (in Estonian)|last=|first=|date=January 29, 2014|website=|publisher=Estonian University of Life Sciences|access-date=August 31, 2016}}</ref> It also reported the chinchilla farms employed 20.5 full-time workers in 2014.<ref name=":0" /> The activists have voiced their concern about the bias inherent in the study, which according to them by and large ignored ethical and environmental arguments, as a number of the experts in the study panel were found to have direct links to and vested interests in the fur industry.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://loomus.ee/animal-advocates-impact-analysis-on-fur-farming-is-biased/|title=Animal advocates: Impact analysis on fur farming is biased|last=|first=|date=|website=loomus.ee|publisher=Animal Advocacy Organization Loomus|access-date=2016-08-31}}</ref> The commission is expected to formulate their opinion and vote whether the petition would move on to a law drafting phase and public discussion in the full quorum of the parliament in the fall of 2016.<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://uudised.err.ee/v/eesti/d7b7f8cf-60bd-4dd2-b065-d3b4136e0720/maaelukomisjon-otsustab-karusloomakasvatuste-saatuse-voimalikult-kiiresti|title=Maaelukomisjon otsustab karusloomakasvatuste saatuse võimalikult kiiresti|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Estonian Public Broadcasting|access-date=2016-08-31}}</ref>
On August 22, 2016, activists launched an additional international petition inviting the [[Riigikogu|Estonian Parliament]] to ban fur farming in the country at change.org.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://loomus.ee/international-petition-calls-on-estonia-to-ban-fur-farms/|title=International petition calls on Estonia to ban fur farms|last=|first=|date=|website=loomus.ee|publisher=Animal Advocacy Organization Loomus|access-date=2016-08-31}}</ref>
===Canada===
====Quebec==== In 2014, for the first time in Canadian history, a Quebec fur farmer by the name of Jean-Luc Rodier was charged with animal cruelty following an investigation by the [[Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals]] (S.P.C.A.). Fox and mink at the fur farm were seized by animal welfare organizations and some were in such poor condition that they had to be euthanized.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://montreal.ctvnews.ca/a-quebec-first-fur-farm-owner-charged-with-cruelty-negligence-1.2094960 |title=A Quebec first: Fur farm owner charged with cruelty, negligence | CTV Montreal News |website=Montreal.ctvnews.ca |date= |accessdate=2017-02-22}}</ref> Following the S.P.C.A. investigation, this Quebec Fur Farm was raided by anonymous activists who set free thousands of animals.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/quebec-farmed-mink-set-free-by-intruder-1.2741807 |title=Quebec farmed mink set free by intruder - Montreal - CBC News |website=Cbc.ca |date=2014-08-20 |accessdate=2017-02-22}}</ref>
====British Columbia==== Video footage taken at Fur Farms in 2014 in British Columbia by the A.P.F.A.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://furbearerdefenders.com/blog/make-fur-history |title=Make Fur History | The Fur Bearers |website=Furbearerdefenders.com |date=2014-10-29 |accessdate=2017-02-22}}</ref> was described by the S.P.C.A. as "inherently inhumane".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/1645709/footage-released-from-b-c-mink-farms-is-horrifying-says-bc-spca/ |title=Footage released from B.C. mink farms is ‘horrifying’ says BC SPCA |website=Globalnews.ca |date=2014-10-30 |accessdate=2017-02-22}}</ref> Animal rights activists in the city of Vancouver have been using legal and illegal actions to protest selling fur such as vandalism, home demonstrations of fur shop owners, and organizing public protests.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://vancouver.mediacoop.ca/story/summary-anti-fur-action-vancouver/15594 |title=Summary of Anti-Fur Action in Vancouver | Vancouver Media Co-op |website=Vancouver.mediacoop.ca |date=2013-01-13 |accessdate=2017-02-22}}</ref>
====Ontario==== Canadian fur farms in the Province of Ontario have been repeatedly targeted by an underground group called [[Animal Liberation Front]] (ALF). Thousands of mink were freed from farms across the province during 2013<ref>{{cite web|author=nurun.com |url=http://www.simcoereformer.ca/2013/08/27/foxes-minks-sprung-from-fur-farm |title=Fox, mink sprung from fur farm | Simcoe Reformer |website=Simcoereformer.ca |date=2013-08-27 |accessdate=2017-02-22}}</ref> and 2015.<ref>{{cite web|author=nurun.com |url=http://www.lfpress.com/2015/07/31/animals-released-from-third-mink-farm |title=Another mink farm hit | The London Free Press |website=Lfpress.com |date=2015-07-31 |accessdate=2017-02-22}}</ref> The mink breeders association of Ontario responded by offering a hundred thousand dollar bounty leading to a conviction of the persons responsible.<ref>{{cite web|author=Steve Rice |url=http://www.torontosun.com/2015/06/04/hefty-reward-offered-to-catch-perpetrators-of-deadly-mink-release |title=Hefty reward offered to catch perpetrators of deadly mink release | Ontario | Ne |website=Torontosun.com |date=2015-06-04 |accessdate=2017-02-22}}</ref> Undercover footage was also released by the ALF in 2015 of several Ontario area mink farms, showcasing injured animals and mink cages covered in feces and maggots.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://directaction.info/news_oct30_15.htm |title=BITE BACK Magazine |website=Directaction.info |date= |accessdate=2017-02-22}}</ref> Animal rights organizations across the province have taken a wide array of actions to stop the fur trade, such as public protests and disruptions of fur fashion shows.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2015/03/27/protestor-toronto-fashion_n_6958520.html |title=Protester Crashes Runway At Toronto Fashion Week |website=Huffingtonpost.ca |date=2015-03-27 |accessdate=2017-02-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://london.ctvnews.ca/anti-fur-advocates-protest-at-channer-s-1.1688337 |title=Anti-fur advocates protest at Channer's | CTV London News |website=London.ctvnews.ca |date=2014-02-15 |accessdate=2017-02-22}}</ref>

{{italic title}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2014}} [[File:Germany Must Perish! cover.jpg|thumb|First edition]] '''''Germany Must Perish!''''' is a 104-page book written by [[Theodore N. Kaufman|Theodore Newman Kaufman]], which he self-published in [[1941]] in the [[United States]]. The book advocated genocide through the sterilization of all [[Germans]] and the territorial dismemberment of Germany, believing that this would achieve world peace. Kaufman founded the Argyle Press in [[Newark, New Jersey]], United States, in order to publish this book. He was the sole proprietor of the Argyle Press and it is not known to have published any other works.
The [[National Socialist German Workers Party|Nazi Party]] used the book, written by a [[Jews|Jewish]] author, to support their argument that Jews were plotting against their country.<ref name=NYT>{{cite news|title=Jews of Hanover Forced from Homes. Mayor Cites American Book, 'Germany Must Perish'|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1941/09/09/archives/jews-of-hanover-forced-from-homes-mayor-cites-american-book-germany.html|newspaper=[[New York Times]]|date=September 9, 1941|accessdate=April 19, 2011 }}</ref>
==American reactions to the book== Though written and self-published by a non-notable author, the book received considerable attention. [[Time (magazine)|''Time'']] magazine published a review in its 24 March issue that compared the book to [[Jonathan Swift]]'s 1729 satirical essay ''[[A Modest Proposal]]'', which proposed reducing the population pressure in Ireland by the cannibalistic consumption of poor Irish children. However, the ''Time'' essay recognized that Kaufman's work was not satirical; it described the book as the "enshrinement of a single sensational idea". "Since Germans are the perennial disturbers of the world's peace, says the book, they must be dealt with like any homicidal criminals. But it is unnecessary to put the whole German nation to the sword. It is more humane to sterilize them."<ref name=rev>{{cite news|title=A Modest Proposal|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,884346,00.html|work=Time magazine|date=March 24, 1941|accessdate=April 19, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=A Modest Proposal (review from ''Time'' magazine)|url=http://www.nizkor.org/ftp.cgi/people/k/kaufman.theodore.nathan/press/time-review-perish-194103|website=The Nizkor Project|accessdate=September 27, 2014}}</ref>
According to one study, reviews in the United States "reflected an odd combination of straight reporting and skepticism".<ref name=Lang>Berel Lang, ''Philosophical Witnessing: The Holocaust as Presence'', [[University Press of New England]]: 2009), pp. 130–131, 135</ref> Kaufman's second and more moderate pamphlet, "No More German Wars" published in 1942, was ignored both in the U.S. and in Germany.<ref name=Lang/>
An advertisement in ''[[The New York Times]]'' stated that the book was released to the public on March 1, 1941. Kaufman also promoted the book by mailing a miniature black cardboard coffin with a hinged lid to reviewers.<ref>Anonymous. Advertisement for ''Germany Must Perish!''. ''New York Times''. March 1, 1941. p. 13</ref> Inside the coffin was a card proclaiming, "Read GERMANY MUST PERISH! Tomorrow you will receive your copy."<ref name=rev/><ref name=Lombardo>{{cite book |last=Lombardo |first=Paul A. |author-link1=Paul_A._Lombardo |date=2010 |title=Three Generations, No Imbeciles: Eugenics, the Supreme Court and Buck v. Bell |url= |location=Baltimore, MD |publisher=Johns Hopkins UP |pages=228, 236 |edition=paperback |isbn=978-0-8018-9824-2}}</ref>
The book's dust jacket contained excerpts from reviews of the book. One [[blurb]] read: "A Plan For Permanent Peace Among Civilized Nations! -- New York Times."<ref>"Latest Books Received." ''New York Times''. March 16, 1941. p. BR29</ref>
In 1945, a Jewish journalist wrote an article claiming that the book was "little more than self-indulgence in dire vituperation by a man who sees Germany as the sole cause of the world's woes".<ref>[[Donald F. Lach]], "What They Would Do about Germany", ''[[Journal of Modern History]]'', Vol. 17, No. 3. (September 1945), pp. 227-243</ref>
==Contents== Kaufman advocated the mass extermination through [[forced sterilization]] of the German people and the territorial dismemberment of Germany after an Allied victory in [[World War II]].<ref name=Lombardo />
Kaufman summarized ''Germany Must Perish!'' in advertisements in the ''[[New York Times]]'' and ''[[New York Post]]'' as: "A dynamic volume outlining a plan for the extinction of Germany and containing a map showing possible dissection and apportionment of its territory."<ref>''New York Post'', Friday, February 28, 1941, p. 22</ref> In an interview carried in the September 26, 1941, issue of ''The Canadian Jewish Chronicle'', Kaufman defended his plan for the "sterilization of all Germans":<ref>{{cite news|author=Harold U. Ribalow|title=Hitler Will Be Nothing But A Rosebud Says Author 'Germany Must Perish!'. One Man's Plan For Peace Forever|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=rPJOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gkwDAAAAIBAJ&dq=theodore-kaufman%20germany%20must%20perish&pg=2325%2C5306|newspaper=The Canadian Jewish Chronicle|page=5|date=September 26, 1941|accessdate=December 4, 2011}}</ref> [[File:GermanyMustPerish2.jpg|thumb|Map showing Kaufman's proposed dismemberment of Germany (and Austria)]]
{{quote|I believe that the Jews have a mission in life. They must see to it that the nations of the world get together in one vast federation. "Union Now" is the beginning of this. Slowly but surely the world will develop into a paradise. We will have perpetual peace. And the Jews will do the most to bring about this confederation, because they have the most to gain. But how can you get peace if Germany exists? The only way to win an eternal peace is to make the punishment of waging war more horrible than war itself. Human beings are penalized for murder, aren't they? Well, Germany starts all the wars of magnitude. Let us sterilize all Germans and wars of world domination will come to an end!}} {{clearleft}}
==The German reaction==
Kaufman was a Manhattan-born Jew and his advocacy of genocide attracted great attention in Germany.<ref name=rev/> The book was denounced as an "orgy of Jewish hatred" and U.S. President [[Franklin Delano Roosevelt|Franklin D. Roosevelt's]] polemical anti-German agitation was seen as having inspired it.<ref>{{cite news|title=Nazis Attack Roosevelt|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1941/07/24/87646724.pdf|accessdate=September 27, 2014|work=New York Times|date=July 24, 1941}}</ref> American journalist [[Howard K. Smith]] was in Germany when ''Germany Must Perish!'' became known. He wrote:<ref>Howard K. Smith, ''Last Train from Berlin'' (London: Phoenix Pr., 1942), p. 134</ref> {{quote|No man has ever done so irresponsible a disservice to the cause his nation is fighting and suffering for than Nathan Kaufman. His half-baked brochure provided the Nazis with one of the best light artillery pieces they have, for, used as the Nazis used it, it served to bolster up that terror which forces Germans who dislike the Nazis to support, fight and die to keep Nazism alive ...}}
In September 1941, [[Julius Streicher]] published an essay in ''[[Der Sturmer]]'' that called Kaufman's book "the crazy thinking of [an] insane Jewish brain". He quoted Kaufman at length and then commented: "By destroying the German people, the Jew wants to stop up the spring from which, since the beginning, the world has always found its creative blood, the source of all that is beautiful, good and noble."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Streicher|first1=Julius|title=The Battle with the Devil|url=http://research.calvin.edu/german-propaganda-archive/ds15.htm|website=German Propaganda Archive|publisher=[[Calvin College]]|accessdate=September 27, 2014}}</ref> [[Joseph Goebbels]] also gave a radio address from Berlin warning Germans of "plans 'for sterilization of our entire population under 60 years' of age".<ref name=Lombardo /> These concerns were echoed by [[Adolf Hitler]] himself after the US entered World War II; he claimed mass sterilization of German male youth was a "primary" American goal.<ref name=Lombardo />
When the Jews of [[Hanover]] were evicted on September 8, 1941, the local authorities cited Kaufman's book as one of the reasons.<ref name=NYT/> Kaufman responded:<ref>{{cite news|title=Hanover Jews Victims of Latest Oppression|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=kxhlAAAAIBAJ&sjid=vW4NAAAAIBAJ&pg=1522,728722&dq=theodore+kaufman+newark&hl=en|newspaper=[[Associated Press]]|date=September 9, 1941|accessdate=April 20, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Unknown Title|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1941/09/09/87665415.pdf|accessdate=September 27, 2014|work=New York Times|date=September 9, 1941}}</ref> {{quote|This is just a flimsy pretext for another of the innate cruelties of the German people ... I don't think it was my book that prompted this barbarity. They employed every possible German cruelty against the Jews long before my book was published.}}
The book appeared in many pieces of [[National Socialist]] propaganda. The ''Parole der Woche''{{'s}} weekly wall newspaper included it as evidence that the Allies' war aims included the destruction of Germany.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://research.calvin.edu/german-propaganda-archive/parolederwoche.htm|title=Parole der Woche|first=Randall|last=Bytwerk|website=research.calvin.edu}}</ref> The pamphlet "The War Goal of World Plutocracy" detailed the contents of the book, although with some omissions from the text that it quoted.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://research.calvin.edu/german-propaganda-archive/kriegsziel.htm|title=War Aims of World Plutocracy|first=Randall|last=Bytwerk|website=research.calvin.edu}}</ref> It was used in 1944 in a pamphlet, "Never!", which described Kaufman's importance:<ref>{{cite web|last1=Goitsch|first1=Heinrich|title=Never!|url=http://research.calvin.edu/german-propaganda-archive/niemals.htm|website=German Propaganda Archive|publisher=Calvin College|accessdate=September 27, 2014}} The use of quotation marks for the last sentence of this quotation is unexplained.</ref> {{quote|The Jewish president of the American Federation of Peace is no anonymous individual, no fanatic rejected by world Jewry, no mentally ill crackpot, but rather a leading and widely known Jewish personality in the United States. He belongs to the so-called Roosevelt Brain Trust, which provides intellectual and political education and advice to the American President. "It is therefore beyond question that his book and its demand that 'Germany must perish' corresponds to the official opinion of the leading circles of world plutocracy."}}
At his [[Nuremberg trial]] Julius Streicher cited Kaufman's book in his defense, claiming his anger at Jews was prompted by ''Germany Must Perish!''.<ref name=Lombardo /> The German philosopher and historian [[Ernst Nolte]] argues that the German reaction to ''Germany Must Perish!'' supports his contention that World War II was a genuine response to German fears of a worldwide Jewish plot.<ref>Nolte, Ernst "Between Myth and Revisionism", pages 17-38 from ''Aspects of the Third Reich'', edited by H.W. Koch (NY: St. Martin's Press, 1985), pp. 27-28</ref>
